Commercial, recreational, and public venues are open with social distancing protocols. Officials may impose stricter measures in case of increased disease activity; additional curbs on nonessential businesses are possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220411173317/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/bangladesh-authorities-lift-quarantine-for-asymptomatic-entrants-pre-departure-covid-19-test-requirement-for-vaccinated-arrivals-as-of-march-10-update-67
There are no restrictions on internal movement.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220411184909/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Fully vaccinated entrants with proof of completing a WHO-approved vaccine regimen no longer need to carry pre-departure test results. At least 14 days must have passed after completing vaccination to be considered as fully vaccinated. Others must submit negative results of a PCR test taken within 72 hours before departure. Outbound travelers from Bangladesh no longer require COVID-19 testing unless mandated by airline authorities or the destination country.    Officials have also lifted the system of varied quarantine periods based on travel origin. Symptomatic entrants - regardless of vaccination status - will undergo on-arrival testing; individuals who test positive must enter self-paid quarantine at a government facility or hotel for at least seven days. A repeat PCR test will occur after seven days; passengers must quarantine until they receive a negative test result.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220411173317/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/bangladesh-authorities-lift-quarantine-for-asymptomatic-entrants-pre-departure-covid-19-test-requirement-for-vaccinated-arrivals-as-of-march-10-update-67

Nepal schools reopened on February 13th:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220214234133/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/south-asia/schools-reopen-in-nepal-as-third-wave-of-covid-weakens/articleshow/89540371.cms

Nepal schools reopened on February 13th. In late April, the 10th-grade students completed their Secondary Education Examination (SEE) in Nepal. There are no restrictions on movements within Nepal with a vaccination certificate. Local and private transportation are available. Public transport and personal vehicles, including taxis, are permitted in the Kathmandu valley and must adhere to COVID protocols.  Violations of local orders may result in penalties. Long distance buses may be operating in some areas of the country. Additional restrictions remain possible in many locations.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220523163119/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307201443/http://www.xinhuanet.com/asiapacific/20220305/c56196aabeb8455abff9a196d31a61d3/c.html

According to MoH Nepal, as of mid May 2022, 76.7% of the population have received the 1st dose and 67.8% are fully vaccinated. About 1 out of 8 Nepalese, 13% of the population has received a booster.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220523165444/https://covid19.who.int/region/searo/country/np/    According to covid-19 vaccine tracker Nepal has adminstered 9 vaccines (Moderna's Spikevax, Pfizer/BioNTech Comirnaty, Gamaleya's Sputnik V, Janssen's Ad26.COV2.S, Oxford/AstraZeneca's Vaxzevria, Serum's Covishield, Bharat Biotech's Covaxin, Sinopharm's Covilo and CoronaVac).  See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220523164846/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/  21 more million doses to be delivered before June 2022:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131191839/https://mohp.gov.np/attachments/article/811/NEPAL%20COVID-19%20EMERGENCY%20RESPONSE%20AND%20HEALTH%20SYSTEMS.pdf    Government began administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for people over 60:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117204601/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/nepal-starts-giving-covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-2022-01-17/

See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220523164846/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/  21 more million doses to be delivered by June 2022:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131191839/https://mohp.gov.np/attachments/article/811/NEPAL%20COVID-19%20EMERGENCY%20RESPONSE%20AND%20HEALTH%20SYSTEMS.pdf    Government began administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for people over 60:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117204601/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/nepal-starts-giving-covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-2022-01-17/

Is public transportation operating?  Yes.  According to the Government of Pakistan, individuals using public transportation â trains or buses â should wear facemasks and keep a distance of at least six feet from other individuals.  Certain provinces may limit the use of public transportation to only allow use by vaccinated individuals  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529113418/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No policy change. All COVID-19 related restrictions lifted across the country, while all restrictions on those not vaccinated remain  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529122804/https://www.dawn.com/news/1680271

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  No.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220529113418/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Domestic Air Travel. Only Fully Vaccinated Pax of 18 Years and above age  (Locals / Foreigners / Diplomats) will be allowed Domestic Air Travel with  effect from 1 st October 2021 with following exceptions: -  Obligatory Vaccination Regime â Revised Inbound / Outbound Air, Land, Sea Travel and Domestic Air Travel COVID Related Protocols  (1) All Foreigners / Foreign Passport holders less than 18 years of age are  allowed Domestic Air Travel without Vaccination.  (2) Pakistani pax less than 15 Years of age are allowed Domestic Air  Travel without Vaccination.  (3) Pakistani pax between 15 to 18 Years of age are allowed Domestic Air  Travel without Vaccination till 01 November 2021.  (4) Pakistani Pax between 15 to 18 years of age will be required to be in  possession of Partial Vaccination Certificate / Proof of Partial Vaccination  i.e at least one dose for Domestic Air Travel with effect from 1 November  2021. Full Vaccination Certificate / Proof of Full Vaccination of Pax  between 15 to 18 years of age will be mandatory for Domestic Air Travel  with effect from 1 December 2021.  (5) Pax with valid medical reason for exemption of vaccination issued by  Doctor (certificate from classified specialist) are allowed Domestic Air  Travel without Vaccination Certificate.  (6) Foreigners / Foreign Passport holders who have travelled to Pakistan from  other countries before 1st October 2021 are allowed to continue their  domestic travel without vaccination certificate.     https://archive.ph/9IN0a

In order to contain BA.2.12.1, a sub-variant of the Omicron strain of Covid-19, Pakistan has expanded the scope of rapid antigen testing at its international airports.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220529132525/https://tribune.com.pk/story/2356781/pakistan-expands-covid-testing-for-inbound-travellers    Only fully vaccinated passengers of age 12 years and above will be allowed to undertake international inbound air travel to Pakistan with subject to exemptions. Any non-vaccinated passengers of age 12 years and above travelling to Pakistan and fulfiling an exemption criteria, will be required to possess a negative PCR test conducted within 72 hours.  Link: https://archive.ph/pXudz    Provision of information through the PASS TRACK app is mandatory for all passengers traveling to Pakistan have to download and install the PASS TRACK app from the Google Play Store / Apple Store and enter their personal details as required.  Mandatory COVID-19 vaccination and possession of proof of COVID-19 vaccination will be applicable for all passengers above 18 years of age.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220529122309/https://www.piac.com.pk/travel-advisory-updates

On 30 March 2020 GoP has approved the fiscal stimulus package of Rs. 1.2 trillion and Supplementary Grant of Rs. 100 billion for the "Residual/Emergency Relief Fund" in relation to provision of funds for mitigating the affect of COVID-19 for the impacted population.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529124344/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/pakistan-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html

Relaxation in trade and cash/government subsidy  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529124344/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/pakistan-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html
Government website: https://web.archive.org/web/20220529131947/https://covid.gov.pk/

Are test results reliably available within one calendar day? Yes.  Currently labs are regularly able to provide COVID-19 test results within the required timeframe.  Testing is currently available both to individuals with symptoms as well as for asymptomatic individuals who need a test for administrative reasons, such as for preflight. The average price of the COVID-19 test is between 6000 and 9000 PKR.  The individual is responsible for the cost of the test.  Results are delivered via email.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220529113418/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All passengers are required to install and register on the PassTrack app prior to issuance of a boarding pass to Pakistan at point of original embarkation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220529113418/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Continue to use the surgical mask in all public places until you are advised.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529134625/https://covid.gov.pk/prevention
